conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, and their shape and size depend on the position and size of the object and the light source.
When the light source is higher, shadows tend to be longer and more spread out.
When the light source moves downward, shadows become shorter and more concentrated.
As the light source moves downward, the shadows will shift closer to their respective objects.
When the light source is higher, shadows are larger because the light rays have to travel a longer distance to reach the ground, spreading out more.
When the light source moves downward, the light rays have a shorter distance to travel, causing the shadows to become smaller and more focused.
Shadow A corresponds to the ice cream object.
Shadow A's position will move closer to the ice cream as the light source moves downward.
Shadow A's size will become smaller as the light source moves downward.
Shadow B corresponds to the typewriter object.
Shadow B's position will move closer to the typewriter as the light source moves downward.
Shadow B's size will become smaller as the light source moves downward.
Shadow C corresponds to the sphere object.
Shadow C's position will move closer to the sphere as the light source moves downward.
Shadow C's size will become smaller as the light source moves downward.
Shadow D corresponds to the cone object.
Shadow D's position will move closer to the cone as the light source moves downward.
Shadow D's size will become smaller as the light source moves downward.
When the light source moves downward, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift closer to their respective objects and will become smaller.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to the objects casting them and will decrease in size when the light source moves downward.
